concepts.title: Back-of-the-Envelope Estimation
concepts.summary: Rapid feasibility checks grounded in common performance numbers—prove your design can handle the load in minutes.

sections.name: Why BOE Matters
points: Foundational for builders/interviewees to validate feasibility in minutes.
Grounded in data and common perf numbers—not guesses.

sections.name: Three Pillars
points: Power of Two (volume): know KB/MB/GB/TB/PB; each TB→PB jump is ~1000x.
Critical Latencies (speed): memory is fast, disk is slow; avoid seeks; compress before network; distance adds latency.
Availability Nines (reliability): 99% vs 99.9% vs 99.999%—higher nines cost exponentially more; know downtime per year.

sections.name: Example: Twitter-Like Estimate
points: Assumptions: 300M MAU, 50% DAU, 2 tweets/day, 10% with media, 5-year retention.
Compute QPS: ~3.5k avg QPS, ~7k peak QPS (rule of 2x).
Storage: 30M media/day at ~1MB each → ~30TB/day → ~55PB over 5 years.

sections.name: Practical Tips
points: Round aggressively; magnitude over precision.
Write assumptions so they can be challenged/adjusted.
Label units to avoid MB/GB mix-ups.
Key estimates: QPS, peak QPS, total storage, cache size, server counts.

sections.name: Latency Lessons
points: Memory is fast; disk seeks are agonizingly slow.
Compress before sending over networks.
Cross-continent latency (~150ms) heavily affects consistency/failover strategies.

sections.name: Availability (Nines)
points: Higher nines demand deep redundancy (hot spares, geo-replication) and cost.

sections.name: Apply & Reflect
points: BOE is a gut check grounded in common numbers—prevents wasted effort on infeasible designs.
Common targets: QPS/peak, storage (esp. media), cache sizing, server counts.
Trade-off: geo-redundancy for HA vs added latency and consistency constraints.
